meanings.definition: To fasten or secure something again with tacks.
meanings.sent1: She had to retack the loose poster on the wall.
meanings.sent2: After the wind blew it off, he had to retack the sail to the boat.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat tried to retack the curtain with its claws.
meanings.sent4: He retacked his confidence after the setback.
meanings.sent5: The idea of failure made him retack his determination with renewed vigor.

meanings.definition: To change direction or course, especially in sailing.
meanings.sent1: The captain decided to retack the ship to avoid the storm.
meanings.sent2: During the race, they had to retack several times to catch the wind.
meanings.sent3: The sailboat had to retack suddenly to avoid a collision.
meanings.sent4: She retacked her plans after receiving new information.
meanings.sent5: The project needed to retack its focus to reach the deadline.

meanings.sent1: The teacher had to retack the student for talking during the lesson.
meanings.sent2: He retacked his son for not completing his homework.
meanings.sent3: She playfully retacked her friend for eating the last cookie.
meanings.sent4: The boss retacked the employee for missing the deadline.
meanings.sent5: The coach retacked the team for their lack of effort in the game.
